elements.title: Improving our response through the Event Control Centre

data.value: Suncorp launched an Event Control Centre (ECC) to enhance disaster preparedness and resilience.
The ECC allows monitoring and responding to severe weather-affected communities through near-real time data.
Combination of geospatial multi-level mapping, satellite and aerial imagery, and AI.
Supports the development of resilience efforts in Australia and shared with industry and government.

data.key: Pre-tax profit on sale of RACT Insurance

data.value: This table presents a downside sensitivity analysis showing the pre-tax profit/loss impact of various economic scenarios. It examines both isolated and combined effects of changes in residential property prices (600 bps decrease), commercial property prices (600 bps decrease), and unemployment rate (100 bps increase). The isolated movements would result in potential losses of $15M, $13M, and $10M respectively. The table also considers a combined scenario where all variables move adversely simultaneously, though the combined impact is not specified.
Decrease weighted average ~600 bps over 2 years from a fall of 14.7% to 20.7% (Impact: $15M loss)
Decrease weighted average ~600 bps over 2 years from a fall of 6.4% to 12.4% (Impact: $13M loss)
Increase ~100 bps over 1 year to 4.8% (Impact: $10M loss)

elements.title: Board Directors' Skills and Competencies Matrix

data.value: Risk management frameworks, setting risk appetite, building and adapting organisational risk culture, regulatory relationships, the effectiveness of leadership.
Implementing organisation-wide governance and compliance frameworks and sustainable practices, regulatory compliance, assessing the relevance and accuracy of measurement systems.
Reviewing and setting organisational strategy and organic and inorganic growth opportunities.
Implementing of financial and capital management strategies, corporate finance restructuring, capital raisings within risk appetite, taxation and actuarial experience.
Experience in developing and delivering customer strategies, meeting customer expectations and delivering the right customer outcomes.
Managing relationships with key stakeholders, including shareholders, government, regulators and leading industry bodies. Influencing public policy decisions and outcomes.
Developing and sustaining the right corporate culture. Protecting and enhancing our reputation. Building stakeholder trust and confidence in organisation. Promotion of ethical 'tone from the top'.
Domestic and/or international experience in Banking, including the regulatory landscape for Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions.
Personal and commercial insurance experience, including the competitive pressures associated with non-traditional market entrants and other sources of disruption.

Broad experience across industries related to the banking and general insurance sectors, for example insurance more generally, reinsurance, funds management, wealth, health insurance, retail stores, technology and/or industries across Suncorp's supply chain.

Experience in leveraging the use of digital channels and technology innovation. Experience in driving strategic insights from the collection and analysis of customer data and industry statistics. Knowledge of data privacy and information security practices.

Experience gained while performing at a senior executive level. Driving engagement and enablement, evaluating employee and executive performance, strategic workforce planning (including change management), leading organisation change in a multi-channel business. Experience with performance assessment and feedback including driving a culture of accountability.
Driving health, safety and well-being strategies, proactive identification and prevention of health and safety risks. Aware of best practice/benchmarks.

Detailed executive remuneration matters (including scorecard target setting), remuneration frameworks and incentive arrangements. Understanding of the relevant legislative/contractual framework for remuneration. Experience in discipline and fair performance assessment and associated awards.
Set out in the Board Charter, available on the governance and policies section of the website.

elements.title: Provisions for employee benefits and restructuring

data.key: Annual leave, long service leave and other employee benefits
data.value: The provision is determined based on expected payments including estimates such as employee service periods, turnover rates, and future salary increases.
A restructuring provision is recognised in relation to changes in the Group’s operating model primarily for redundancy costs.
Termination benefits are recognised as an expense when the Group can no longer withdraw the offer of those benefits, especially in case of voluntary redundancies.

Adjusted NPAT provides stakeholders with a clearer view of the Group's underlying profitability. The measure is more closely aligned to the areas which management can control such as risk selection, pricing and cost control, whilst also driving longer- term shareholder value creation.
Cash Return on Tangible Equity (Cash RoTE)

Cash RoTE is a measure of Suncorp's overall return to shareholders. It illustrates how effective Suncorp is at turning the cash put into the business into greater gains and growth for the organisation and investors.

Measuring Suncorp's growth versus System for Insurance (Australia), Suncorp New Zealand, and Home Lending provides an outcome relative to the market whilst also separating the impact of changes to market.
Net Promoter Score (NPS) is aligned to our Purpose of building futures and protecting what matters.
Focusing on risk and compliance is likely to lead to better anticipation and mitigation of key risks which can positively impact resilience, growth and financial performance.

Real-time results on employee engagement enable Suncorp to transform feedback into action plans. The Gender Pay Gap is aligned to Suncorp's ambition of leading the way in advocating for social change.

data.key: Meaningful weighting of non-financial measures in the Group Scorecard
data.value: The structure of the Group Scorecard consists of a number of measures across the categories of Financial, Customer, Risk, and People and Culture, with financial measures and non-financial measures equally weighted at 50% each.

data.key: STI outcomes are based on both the "what" and the "how"
data.value: For executives, the Board considers behaviours as part of its judgement overlay in determining STI outcomes. For other employees, individual scorecards are weighted 80% towards performance measures and 20% towards the Being @ Suncorp behaviours, with the intent of ensuring that performance outcomes are achieved in the appropriate way.

data.key: The behavioural STI gateway and modifier linked to the Code of Conduct
data.value: The behavioural STI gateway and modifier is based on an employee's compliance with the Code of Conduct. This can lead to an employee's STI being reduced (down to nil) if they do not adhere to the Code of Conduct.

data.key: The Board's application of a judgement overlay on the Group Scorecard outcome
data.value: In determining performance and remuneration outcomes, the People and Remuneration Committee considers adherence to effective risk management practices and all other relevant factors in the context of the Group's risk appetite. This occurs before the Board makes its final determination of the overall STI pool and individual STI awards for the executives.

data.key: Incorporation of malus and clawback criteria into deferred incentive awards
data.value: Deferred incentives (including STI deferred awards and vested and unvested LTI awards) are subject to malus and clawback criteria based on the Board's judgment. Malus and clawback criteria enable the Board, in its absolute discretion and subject to compliance with the law, to determine that a participant's deferred incentives will be fully or partially lapsed (malus) during the deferral period or any shares or cash payment made will be fully or partially forfeited, lapsed and / or repaid (clawback). In exercising its discretion, the Board will consider whether this is necessary to protect the Group's financial soundness or to respond to unforeseen circumstances.

Suncorp Group's Securities Trading Policy regulates dealing by directors, employees and contractors in Suncorp securities and prohibits hedging transactions to limit the economic risk of a holding in the Company's securities including unvested rights. All KMP are reminded of this policy at least twice per year, usually in the month prior to the release of Suncorp Group's annual and half-yearly financial results. Any subsequent dealing in those shares is subject to the terms of the Securities Trading Policy. Further detail can be found in the FY22 Corporate Governance Statement at suncorpgroup.com.au/about/corporate-governance.

Consumer Brand NPS for AAMI was at target. There was improvement in AAMI NPS through FY22, noting that high claims volumes and pricing pressure provided headwinds in the latter part of the year.

Consumer (MFI) Brand NPS for Suncorp Bank was between threshold and target. Digital migration caused some transitionary pain points for customers through FY22, along with associated impacts to service levels.

Digital Sales and Service targets were both exceeded. Strong digital sales results were driven by improvements across Home sales (+28%) and Motor sales (+13%). Digital transactions grew 23% with digital registrations increasing by 50% and logins up 35%.
Performance was slightly below target. The Group managed a Severe risk environment well, with most scorecard measures meeting or exceeding target.
Exceptional people empowered to make a difference every day
Employee engagement achieved at stretch, increasing from 79 to 8.3 out of 10.0, placing Suncorp within Top 25% of Finance industry.
Exceptional people empowered to make a difference every day
GPG decreased from 19.6% to 18.4%, slightly below target of 18.3%. On track for FY25 target of 15.5%.

Assessed at target. Strategic Workforce Plan delivered new insights, with significant progress in culture development and productivity measures.

data.key: performance rights that met the performance measure

data.value: Cash ROE is based on the 3-year weighted average of FY20 Cash ROE (20%), F¥21 Cash ROE (30%) and FY22 Cash ROE (50%). Under the FY20 Cash ROE grant, there is — no vesting where Cash ROE is below 9% — 50% vesting where Cash ROE is 9% — 100% vesting where Cash ROE is 10% — straight line vesting where Cash ROE is between 9% and 10%. Average weighted Cash ROE over the period was 6.21%. Given this, the FY20 Cash ROE LT! awards lapsed and the executives received no value from this award.

elements.title: Non-Executive Director Remuneration and Shareholding Policies

data.value: Compulsory superannuation guarantee contributions (SGC) are paid on the director's fee on behalf of all eligible non-executive directors, unless a non-executive director is receiving SGC from more than one employer and has elected to opt out of receiving the contributions.

The Company's general practice is to cap SGC at 10% of the Maximum Contribution Base (MCB) (10.5% in FY23). Superannuation in excess of the MCB is delivered in the form of fees, unless the non-executive director has elected to make voluntary additional superannuation contributions.

Non-executive director aggregate fees are within the shareholder-approved maximum aggregate total remuneration limit of $3,500,000 including SGC. This fee pool has remained the same since it was last increased in 2007.
Non-executive directors have four years from the October following their appointment to achieve the MSR, equivalent to 100% of their base fees.
Base fees refer to the Board Chairman fee or Board Member fee only (excluding Committee fees and SGC).
Based on their shareholding as at 30 June 2022, all non-executive directors have either met, or are on track to meet, the MSR within the required timeframes.

elements.title: Expected Credit Loss (ECL) Provisions for Loans and Advances

data.value: Expected credit loss (ECL) provisions for loans and advances held at amortised cost are a key audit matter due to the significance of the balance of loans and advances held at amortised cost to the financial statements and the inherent complexity of the Group's ECL models.
AASB 9 Financial Instruments (AASB 9) requires significant judgement to estimate expected credit losses.

Testing key controls relating to: reconciliation of relevant data used in the ECL model; assessment of the credit quality of business lending counterparties; controls over systems recording lending arrears; Group’s monitoring mechanisms for loans experiencing signs of stress.
As of 30 June 2022, economic uncertainty remains heightened, leading to significant judgement in developing forward-looking macro-economic scenarios.
The Group’s ECL model governance and validation processes are examined for adequacy and effectiveness.
Post-model adjustments to the ECL results address known model limitations or emerging trends in the loan portfolios.
complies with Section 300A of the Corporations Act 2001
The Directors of the Company are responsible for the preparation and presentation of the Remuneration Report.

elements.title: Suncorp Bank Business Initiatives Progress FY22

data.value: Home lending growth of $41 billion in FY22 and outperformed system reaching 1.8 times system in 2H22.

Targeted investments in customer and broker experiences supported a significant increase in home loan customer NPS and broker NPS and a reduction in median application turnaround times. Suncorp Bank Main Financial Institution (MFI) NPS! was +13.7
At-call transaction portfolio grew 20.6% over the year, with continued MFI customer growth, supported by a strong digital offering.
Launched Buy Now Pay Later product linked to customer's core transactional account and banking app, Suncorp PayLater, to provide additional payment flexibility to customers.
Debit cards are now issued with recycled materials and tactile indicators to support vision-impaired customers.
Business lending developed significant momentum over the second half, delivering six consecutive months of growth.
predominately driven by a 272% increase in business transaction deposits. Digital service redraw facilities delivered alongside enhanced SME loan products have

enabled more customers to access finance. Suncorp Bank completed the migration of personal customers to the Suncorp App, enabling the decommissioning of the legacy mobile banking app and focusing future

investment on the core Suncorp App. Digital engagement and origination capabilities continued to strengthen, including joint account online origination, pre-filled income and expense data and the launch of a refreshed broker
portal. Continued to expand and upskill direct lenders, delivering leading service and customer experiences through the direct channel.
A new arrangement with ATMx provides fee-free access to an additional 1,800 ATMs nationally.
Installed braille functionality across ATMs and launched Translating and Interpreting Services across branches, business banking and call centres.

In line with the increasing customer shift to digital origination and self-service, the Bank continued to optimise the branch network, with the branch footprint reducing from 83 to 64 FY22. The Bank's strategy is to focus customer interactions high value.

Continued momentum with a targeted focus on deepening broker relationships and offering compelling market propositions delivered through trusted brands. Increased market share by 134 basis points over the preceding 12 months, registering seven consecutive quarters of market share gains.

Continued progress to deliver a single claims platform, introducing new channels for customer engagement and seamless connectivity. Automated claims assessment in the second half, resulting in reduced field assessment handling time and improved data accuracy.
Continued progress on enabling broker connectivity with a pilot scheduled for early in FY23.

elements.title: Business Initiatives and FY22 Progress Report

data.value: — Invested in marketing and new product innovation to support growth. — AAMI, the most considered national insurance brand, achieved a Net Promoter Score
NPS}! of +6.0, while also growing in Home and Motor. — Gross Written Premium (GWP] growth of 9.2% when normalised for portfolio exits. Growth broad based portfolios and in the second half of the
was across stronger inancial year, up 10.7% excluding portfolio exits. — Strong Compulsory Third Party (CTP) unit growth of 10%, driven by digitisation in New
South Wales and particularly solid unit growth in South Australia. — Invested in a modern, analytics-driven pricing engine and disciplined portfolio y pricing eng p Pp
management to improve margins and loss ratios. — Deployed the Customer and Pricing Ecosystem (CaPE) for home mass brands. Delivery is
underwriting property, liability packages improve risk selection and efficiency. —
Increased digital sales for mass brands across Home, Motor and CTP products to 61% of all sales and 37% of all service transactions, up from 54% and 31% respectively. —

Focused on making purchasing simple with reduced friction and making self-service accessible, simple and intuitive. Deployed automation initiatives in Direct Distribution, including the implementation of
— Insurance sales and service long-term target of 70% digital/30% voice.

— Digital lodgement of Motor and Home claims more than doubled in FY22. — First in market for digital lodgement and early intervention has delivered better customer experience and outcomes for personal injury claims. — Reconfigured supply chain through a review of home and motor repairer panels, which is expected to drive improved repair quality, capacity and cost outcomes. — Successfully implemented technology solutions to better manage builder panel allocation and performance outcomes, as well as benchmarking claims costs against agreed contracted rates and industry benchmarks.
Shannons Club online community had more than 1.6 million unique visitors
sales up more than 25% for the year
more than 700 motoring events across Australia
Conduct event planning, scenario analysis and simulations to test responses

data.value: Disruptive external events, macro-economic trends, climate change, workforce changes, cyber risk, changes in customer behaviour and competitive responses.
These events have disrupted supply chains, causing rising costs and labor shortages.
Suncorp conducts climate scenario analysis to understand risks associated with climate change.
Evolving cyber threats necessitate enhanced risk frameworks.

elements.title: Climate Risk Assessment and Scenario Analysis

data.value: Findings fall within the variability of natural hazard assumptions and are managed by reinsurance and natural hazard pricing. Higher levels of customer acceptance to flood risk anticipated.
Appropriate controls ensure exposure to short to medium-term climate change risk remains low. Ensuring appropriate insurance cover is in place is paramount to the Bank continuing to support.
The impact of riverine flooding on the New Zealand home insurance portfolio found to be a more significant driver of Average Annual Loss than storm risk under an extreme scenario.
The physical risk associated with the overall investment portfolio are low based on the majority of assets allocated to Fixed Interest which includes government bonds and corporate credit.

elements.title: Building our understanding of physical climate risks

data.value: Analysis of climate change impacts on natural hazard claims, focusing on physical risks and insurance affordability.
130,000 claims from 35 natural hazard events; increased exposure to risks for customers; lower socioeconomic communities are at higher risk.
Management of risks through pricing, natural hazard allowance, and reinsurance.
Expected increase in Average Annual Loss (AAL) due to climate change; advocacy for resilient built environments.
Impacts expected to be pronounced under RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5 climate scenarios.
Continuing to build understanding of climate risks in FY23 following the Climate Change Scenario Analysis Roadmap.

elements.title: Climate Risk Management and Financial Performance

data.value: Recognised as a strategic risk within Enterprise Risk Management Framework (ERMF).
Models built to assess climate change impacts on natural hazards like cyclones, floods, and bushfires.
Risk models used to determine economic capital for identified risks.
Cost and variability of natural hazards drive insurance premiums, affecting affordability.

elements.title: IT Systems Audit Matter and Response

data.value: The Group's businesses utilise a number of interdependent IT systems to process and record a high volume of transactions. Controls for access and changes to IT systems are critical to the recording of financial information and the preparation of a financial report which provides a true and fair view of the Group's financial position

data.key: How the matter was addressed in our audit
data.value: Working with our IT specialists, we tested key automated controls and the control environments that support the consistent operation of these. The in-scope systems were assessed at both an entity level and process level with respect to the controls that were identified as relevant to financial reporting. Our procedures included:

a key audit matter and our audit approach could significantly differ depending on the effective operation of the Group's IT controls. KPMG IT specialists were used throughout the engagement as a core part of our audit team.

data.key: How the matter was addressed in our audit
data.value: by checking approved inspecting the reports regarding the granting and removal of access rights. We also tested controls related to monitoring of access rights. * testing controls used to request, document, develop, test and authorise changes to the functionality and configuration of core systems relevant to in-scope automated controls. We also tested controls related to the appropriateness of users with access to request, authorise, and release changes into the production environment of core systems relevant to financial reporting. e testing the operating effectiveness of automated controls key to our audit testing in relation to system calculations, the generation of reports, and operation of system enforced access controls. Where we noted or effectiveness matters

data.key: How the matter was addressed in our audit
data.value: design operating relating to IT system or application controls relevant to our audit, we performed alternative audit procedures. We also identified and tested mitigating controls in order to respond to the impact on our overall audit approach

Consulting on extending the Banking Executive Accountability Regime (BEAR) to all APRA regulated entities and creating the Financial Accountability Regime.
A number of items have been actioned by Government in response to the 2019 Royal Commission report.
ASIC administering its product intervention power to ban financial products at risk of significant consumer detriment.
Implementing standards on financial contingency planning and recovery planning.
ASIC supervising financial product Design and Distribution Obligations (DDO).
Passing of the Treasury Laws Amendment (Consumer Data Right) Act 2019.
APRA consultation on operational resilience prudential requirements.
APRA consulting on updated requirements across APRA-regulated industries.
Conducted surveys to assess the work of regulated entities in building effective risk culture.
APRA's focus on integrating AASB 17 Insurance Contracts into capital frameworks.
Response decisions leading to the establishment of a $10 billion reinsurance pool.
Addressing financial impacts and community uncertainties over pandemic coverage.
Oversight and guidance from APRA and ASIC.
Commencement of revised obligations for remuneration frameworks, practices, and disclosures.
Regulation of RG 271 Internal Dispute Resolution by ASIC.
APRA consulting on stress testing guidance.
Bringing insurance claims under the financial services provisions of the Corporations Act.
Proposed extension to small business insurance contracts.
Continuing focus on risk culture and conducting risk culture surveys.

data.key: Guidelines for Licensing Non-Operating Holding Companies

elements.title: Regulatory Overview and Changes in New Zealand Insurance Operations

data.value: Requires insurers, banks, and non-bank deposit takers to be licensed and have a fair conduct program to ensure consumer fairness. Expected to come into force in early 2025.
Proposed reforms to New Zealand’s insurance contract law, including changes to disclosure requirements and unfair contract terms, with legislation expected to be introduced in mid-2023.

data.key: Review of IPSA and Solvency Standards
data.value: Reserve Bank of New Zealand is reviewing the Insurance (Prudential Supervision) Act 2010 and Solvency Standards, with interim standards effective January 2023. Full legislation is not expected before end of 2024.
Requires mandatory climate-related financial disclosures for large insurers, applicable from accounting periods starting on or after January 1, 2023.
NZ EQC cap to increase from $150,000 to $300,000 effective October 1, 2022. New Bill aims to improve resilience against natural hazards and clarify coverage.
Government considering a scheme for income replacement cover for redundancies or incapacity due to health conditions, possibly operational by 2024.
Contingent assets are not recognised, but are disclosed in the consolidated financial statements when inflows are probable.
Contingent liabilities are not recognised, but are disclosed in the consolidated financial statements unless the possibility of settlement is remote.

The Group conducts its own internal reviews of its regulatory compliance, which may result in investigation costs, administrative costs, legal costs, system changes, and compensation or remediation payments.
A number of non-compliance instances identified and disclosed to ASIC, APRA, AUSTRAC and FMA.
The assessment focused on non-individual customer identification procedures and other compliance matters.
The Group is subject to ASIC’s Institutional Supervision Program, with ongoing reviews.
The Group is undertaking programs to resolve prior issues impacting customers.
The Australian Financial Complaints Authority can award compensation for customer complaints.
The report details ongoing litigation against AAI Limited concerning addon insurance products sold between May 2006 and June 2018, with a class action filed and the group defending the case.
Following the 2019 Royal Commission report, the Group has actioned some recommendations and is monitoring legislative changes.
Involves litigations concerning business interruption insurance due to COVID-19, with two test cases assessing policy exclusions and responses.
Indication of various other outstanding court proceedings, potential fines, inquiries, and that there may be additional judicial determinations.
A settlement has been achieved in a class action against SPSL, requiring court approval.
Warranties provided during business sales, with no claims outstanding as of June 30, 2022, but future outflows remain uncertain.
Helping our customers and communities build resilience to natural hazards including floods, cyclones, storms, earthquakes and bushfires.
Proactively adapting to and managing the physical and transitional risks and opportunities of climate change for Suncorp’s business.
Ensuring all customers can access affordable financial services that meet their needs.
Developing agile, innovative and accessible solutions and products for customers.
Rapidly adapting to and mitigating evolving data privacy and security threats to protect Suncorp and our customers.
Now being captured as part of environmental stewardship.
The outcomes and insights from our FY22 materiality refresh will continue to inform Suncorp’s advocacy strategy and sustainability program.

elements.title: Climate Governance and Climate Change Risk Management

data.value: Climate change is a strategic risk for Suncorp Group.
Ultimate accountability of climate-related risk management including approval of the Group’s CCAP.
Oversight of the Group’s management of climate-related risks including climate change scenario analysis.
Oversight and review of ELT’s periodic climate-related corporate reporting, specifically TCFD.
Accountable for managing climate-related strategy, business planning, risks and opportunities including implementation and delivery of our CCAP.
Monitor and oversee progress on the implementation of the CCAP.

Topics presented include revised Climate Change Action Plan, flood modelling performance, Natural Hazard Resilience Strategy, Climate Change Scenario Analysis Roadmap, net-zero GHG emission target updates.

Measure additional Scope 3 categories and set targets for emissions reduction.
Bank aims to be an accredited carbon neutral bank through nature-based carbon removal offsets.
Financed emissions amount for around 92% of a financial services company’s total value-chain emissions intensity.
Increased to US$45 per tCO2-e from US$38 per tCO2-e in FY21.
Phasing out by 2025 exposure to thermal coal extraction and electricity generation activities.

data.value: The Risk Committee assists the Board in overseeing the processes used by management to identify, assess, and manage risk.
The Risk Committee reviews an independent report on the appropriateness, effectiveness and adequacy of Suncorp’s ERMF at least every three years.
Endorses annual declarations to APRA regarding risk management as mandated by APRA’s Prudential Standard CPS 220.

Suncorp aims to create an inclusive work environment and has a dedicated policy for diversity and inclusion.
